project.teaser: CRAEFT will deepen our understanding of making activities that include care, judgement, and dexterity standing on Anthropology, Knowledge Representation, Cognitive Science, Art History, Advanced Digitisation, Audiovisual & Haptic Immersivity, and Computational Intelligence to...
project.objective:
CRAEFT will deepen our understanding of making activities that include care, judgement, and dexterity standing on Anthropology, Knowledge Representation, Cognitive Science, Art History, Advanced Digitisation, Audiovisual & Haptic Immersivity, and Computational Intelligence to cover the multifaceted expression of crafts as living and developing heritage, as a sustainable source of income, and as the expression of the mind through imagery, technology, and sedimented knowledge. A generative approach will prove sufficiency for digital conservation, reenactable preservation, and scaling of approach for the full range of materials and techniques.
CRAEFT will catalyse craft education and training with intuitive digital aids, telecommunications, craft-specific simulators, advanced immersivity, and high-end digitisation, to widen access, economise learning, increase exercisability, and relax remoteness constraints in craft learning. The integration of haptics intelligence haptics in digital design connects tacit knowledge in computer-aided craft-specific design tools. Workflow simulation will support experimental archaeology for the recovery of lost techniques. The analytic workflow analysis leads to digital fabrication opportunities for menial tasks, material savings and reuse, and reduction of energy consumption.
Digital dimensions attached to individual works of craft will enable certification and attachment of digital content, but also enable reputation and community building, supported by a Community Portal for professionals and the public that connects to the New Media, hosts heterogeneous craft portforlios, and registers practitioner credentials.
The efficacy of the approach will be piloted in eight representative craft instances with the cross-cutting objectives of Craft Education & Training, Design, Valorisation, and Community services across the range of materials.
project.title: Craft Understanding, Education, Training, and Preservation for Posterity and Prosperity
project.keywords: Education, Training, Action, Cognition, Simulation, Digitisation, Haptics, Immersivity

details.authors: Aldo Xhako, Antonis Katzourakis, Theodoros Evdaimon, Emmanouil Zidianakis, Nikolaos Partarakis, and Xenophon Zabulis

result.title: Communication Plan and Activities
result.description: The communication plan (M2) will contain the intentions of Craeft on communication actions, per type of medium (i.e. social, mass media, participation in events etc.). The plan will define the modus operandi and the timeframe of interaction between partners and MDE regarding the contribution of content for the communication actions. The plan will include templates with instructions to systematise the contribution of partners to the communication activities. The plan will be accompanied by a shared electronic document for the systematic submission of this content. The reports (M12, M24, and M36), will regard the communication activities of Craeft per reporting period. The final version will contain an annex of all the newsletters published and state the consortium plan for post-project communication activities. Also, all newsletters will be available through the project website, at the time of their publication.

details.authors: Petros Stavroulakis, Theodore Ganetsos and Xenophon Zabulis 3

result.title: Action and affordance modelling
result.description: Modelling craft actions regards their functional modelling in software so that they can be reenacted in simulation. Actions will be modelled in terms of required affordances, functional specification, and result prediction. The model will be generative in that when executed it should predict the outcome of an action, in terms of physical result and sensory signal generation. The functional part of this model is to be provided by D3.1. The specification will define the immersive properties and formats so that they can be reenacted in simulation. The first version (M12) reports on the model design and provides the preliminary simulation on the computer. The second version (M24) will update the model and integrate with the immersive presentation using visual and haptic immersive modalities. Each version of this deliverable consists of a report, software, data, and demonstrators.

result.title: Networking and Coordination
result.description: On the reports of the networking actions performed by Craeft and the participation of the consortium in coordination actions and events. The first version (M12) will contain an analytical mapping of the targeted organisations and stakeholders, the plans of action for the duration of the project, and the pertinent activities during the first reporting period. The second and third versions (M24 and M36), will update the plan and report the activities for the corresponding reporting periods.

result.title: Exploitation Plan and Activities
result.description: The exploitation plan for the Craeft outcomes and the reports on its update and implementation. The first version (M12) will identify the planned project outcomes and will map them to stakeholder groups, as well as provide a plan of which organisations and companies will be reached, outline the activities for the exploitation of project outcomes, and report upon these activities for the first year. The second and third versions (M24 and M36), will update the plan and report the activities for the corresponding reporting periods. All versions of this deliverable will report on the organisation and outcomes of the roundtables and project cluster meetings, organised in the context of Task 7.4.

details.authors: Xenophon Zabulis, Partarakis Nikolaos, Vasiliki Manikaki, Ioanna Demeridou, Arnaud Dubois, Inés Moreno, Valentina Bartalesi, Nicolò Pratelli, Carlo Meghini, Sotiris Manitsaris, Gavriela Senteri

result.title: Dissemination Plan and Activities
result.description: The dissemination plan (M2) will contain the intentions of Craeft on dissemination action, per type of planned research and innovation action. The plan will outline the research areas for dissemination and map the scientific collaborations that will lead to joint papers. Moreover, the plan will report on the intentions of the consortium to establish agreements with publishers that will support the Open Access availability of Craeft publications and reduce their cost (e.g. agreements on special issues in journals or special sessions/workshops for conferences. The plan will also target the scientific fora where Creaft publications will have the optimal scientific impact. The plan will be accompanied by a shared electronic document to collect the references to the scientific contribution of partners. The reports (M12, M24, and M36), will update the communication activities of Craeft per reporting period. The final version will contain an annex with references to the publications of Craeft, as well as the reach of the dissemination events where Craeft outcomes were disseminated.

result.title: Knowledge collection and representation
result.description: Reports on the application of the advanced ethnographic methods (D1.1) to the RCIs, the collection of the corresponding data, the formation of knowledge elements, and the digital preservation of both. The output is datasets consisting of digital assets and semantic annotations (data and knowledge) in open and machine-interpretable formats. The first version (Μ12) contains the collection and organisation of data into knowledge, for each RCI. The second version (Μ24) contains the insights obtained from data analysis, the ingestion of data and knowledge in the CAP, and the provision of machine-interpretable representations of both data and knowledge in OpenAIRE repositories.

details.authors: Panagiotis Koutlemanis, Xenophon Zabulis, Nikolaos Stivaktakis, Nikolaos Partarakis, Emmanouil Zidianakis, Ioanna Demeridou

result.title: Enhanced ethnographic methods
result.description: Design of ethnographic methods supported by digital technologies and their rationale. Includes a good practice guide and a reproducible description of the recommended methods. The first version (Μ12) will be on the design and definition of the rationale of the approach, the identification of recording and interviews, the necessary processing and organisation of the acquired data to produce knowledge, and the authoring of reproducible instructions for ethnographers. The second version (Μ24) reports on the application and testing of these methods, improvements realised after their application, and a publication in the form of a good practice guide, published as a handbook under OpenAIRE.

result.title: Maker-Material-Negotiation model and CAP
result.description: The formal, machine-interpretable specification of the Maker-Material Negotiation model and the CAP implementation, along with documentation for both. The model will represent physical information about the objects, tools, gestures, grip postures, their motion, their affordances, and their interaction with materials. The model will be functional in that it functionally explains the scene and is capable of representing its multiple possible outcomes. The CAP will implement this model and enable the authoring of craft action representations. The CAP will map the semantic representation of the action with the functional specification of the action and its affordances. The CAP will provide the UI to author craft representations that are both semantic and functional. The first version (M12) will provide the model design and a preliminary, functional version of the CAP. The second version (M24) will provide its update and report on the use of the CAP for the representation of RCIs and its use to support the Community Portal. Each version of this deliverable consists of a report and software. The second version contains a guide to the authoring of craft representations using the CAP as an OpenAIRE publication.

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
